Posts.Content: I asked my surgeon if my nerves were in there just flapping around in the breeze since they werent attached to the prostate. If I understood her right they are now attached to some veins.

Posts.Title: Possible cure for post-prostatectomy ED on the horizon?

Posts.Content: The hospital put a stick on loc on my thigh as well,I woke up with it already on after surgery. it stayed all week no problem even though I took showers daily starting on day 3. The glue on that thing was so good I think it would have stayed for a month. Having them peel it off my thigh was worse than when they took the cath out. Might be a good idea to shave the top part of your thighs from inside to front the night before your surgery. I came home with a leg bag, switched to the big bag as soon as I got home and left it on all week, until I went back to the doctor to get the cath out I put the leg bag back on for that outing. Otherwise I stayed in the house all week. I bought some addias sweat pants with side snaps so I could route the cath out the side about mid thigh. I got them one size larger than I normally wear, good thing as my abdoman was swollen. I also got underware one size larger and glad I did.

Posts.Title: A couple of post op questions

Posts.Content: Had my surgery on wed morning. Doing ok so far. No pain, just minor discomfort getting up and down or when coughing. Havent had any pain killer stronger than tylenol since 6 pm day of surgery. Havent even needed tylenol the last 2 days. Its day 4 (not including day of surgery) and have a couple questions 1. I havent had a bowl movement yet. Thought I was close a couple of times, but nothing yet. I've been eating regular food since thursday night, and been taking stool softners. Is this normal for it to take this long? I dont feel any discomfort in that dept at this point. At what point should I use a laxitive to get things moving? 2. I will get my cath out this coming wed. I understand after it comes out I'll be leaking a lot, should I take some of the Depends underwear to wear home, or use a Depend ultra guard in my regular underwear? I live 2 hours from the drs office so wondering what to take with me. 2 questions I never thought I would be asking on the internet, lol...........
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: A couple of post op questions

Posts.Content: This is fresh on my mind, as I had mine done 17 days ago. one thing to remember is strong prescription pain killers can cause constipation, so you want to get off of those as soon as possible. In my case (and lots of other that I read about) there wasnt any really sharp pain after surgery, just being uncomfortable with the gas that they used to inflate me to make more room during surgery. I didnt take anything stronger than tylenol after 6 pm the day of surgery, I didnt need it. If you can get up and walk the evening of surgery it will help get rid of that gas. As for getting out of bed, I found that I had to get up differently. I would roll over on my side at the edge of the bed, then sit up SIDEWAYS and swing my legs down to the floor at the same time, rather than the traditional way of sitting straight up then swiveling around and putting my legs down. As for what you need to have on hand, you will need to keep taking stool softner for several days. make sure you have enough tylenol or advil. I had them give me a script for oxycontin, in case I needed it, but I never did. They will probably give you a script for an antibiotic to start taking when they remove the cath in a week. I would also get one package each of some incontinence products. get a box of the light sheilds, one of the maximum guards, one of the full briefs, and a box of the absorbant bed liners. Everyone is different on how dry they are after cath removal, so you wont know what you need until that time. When you go back for cath removal in a week take some of the max guards with you and leave the rest at home. When you get home with the cath they will send you home with a leg bag a large bag for nighttime. as soon as I got home I put the large bag on and left it on all week and never left home. I had some sweat pants that snapped up the side, so I could route the tube out the side of the sweats about mid thigh, and carried the bag around in a bucket. I usually had to empty the bag out once in the middle of the night. Just remember not to overdo it when you get home, walk some but get plenty of rest. You should not pick up anything over 10 lbs for the 6 weeks after. putting on socks was the hardest thing, my wife did that for me the first few days.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for RALP, what do I need onhand?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ljames I keep reading how important it is to exercise and have a low BMI and generally keep excess weight off when dealing with PCa. I know this is generally good advice for most conditions, by is there a reason why it's important for PCa in particular? I had Da Vinci surgery 7 weeks ago. I was suprised when I was completely continent upon cath removal, and have been dry since. The only time I consiously kagel since surgery is if I cough. I know I'am very fortunate from what I have read, and I wonder what I owe that good fortune to, and if it would help others facing surgery. I had a very experienced surgeon, and Because I had an intermediate risk cancer, I was able to put off my surgery for 2 months due to some things going on in my life, and I spent that time practicing Kagels. And even though I'am not ripped like I was when I was 18, I'am in fairly decent shape for my age. At my job I spend a lot of time climbing ladders, getting up and down off my knees working on things. I wonder if that was working on my pelvic floor muscles all these years and didnt know it. I wonder if its a combination of all of the above, plus maybe some dumb luck thrown in. I know there is no guarantees, but I think it is worth getting in shape and doing Kagels before surgery, it sure cant hurt....
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: Why are weight loss & exercise important to fight PCa

Posts.Content: I had surgery at the end of Nov, so I'am a few weeks ahead of him. Things are still changing in the sex dept for me as time goes on. 5 weeks ago I was dissapointed on how things were going in that dept. Things are working much better now, they changed a lot in the last month. Not like they were before, but much better. still have to use viagra and/or a pump. My point is your husband is still healing and hopefully things will improve. Orgasms are much different for me now. I actually feel it more in my legs now. He should mention it to his surgeon, but things may get better. I know its hard to be patient, I felt the same way
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: Orgasm post RALP

Posts.Content: I have been reading this fourm since I was diagnosed this summer, not every day, but occasionally. I've posted a couple of times. I am scheduled for RP in Nov. Since I've been diagnosed I have had some times when I feel down and I tell myself there are others worse than me, suffering worse cancer or other problems. Those moments dont last long. Going forward I was hoping to use this forumn for not only helpful information, but moral support when I was feeling down as all of you have been through what I'am going through. My wife is very supportive but naturally hasnt been through this. Same way with other friends and family. Being able to vent my feelings to people who would understand would be theropy to me. But after reading the thread started by SubDennis and reading the replies, I dont think this is the place. I will go elsewhere to find support I'am outta here......

Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: scheduling surgery after a holiday.....

Posts.Content: Had the surgery wed morning. Surgeon said everything went fine and was able to do nerve sparing. Wed night I went for short walk in hospital, couldnt sit upright in chair due to gas pressure in abdomin. Was able to pass some gas in the night, much better next day and went home. took only tylonol after 6 pm day of surgery Day 2 feeling ok, no pain, just some discomfort. Doing plenty of rest with some walking mixed in. Getting used to the cath and figuring out how to operate while carrying my "little buddy" in a bucket around with me. Everything so far is just as described by those who have gone before. Thanks for the info I knew what to expect. Will go back next wed for cath removal and hopefully find out the path report on the prostate.
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: scheduling surgery after a holiday.....

Posts.Content: I am the same age as your husband and had similar PSA and biopsy results, and have gone through the same decision making process. There is no need to rush into a decision. I would definatly send the slides to Dr Epstien for a 2nd opinion. I was a Gleason 7 (3+4). If the 2nd opnion came back Gleason 6 I was going to consider AS. Mine came back confirming the G7 so based on that and family history I decided on treatment. I was glad I had the 2nd opinion for my piece of mind that I was making the right decision. It took about 2 weeks to get my results back from Epsteins lab. I recommend writing down a list of questions and taking a recording device to meetings with drs so you can review it later, there is a lot to absorb mentally at the meetings. Driving home after one my wife n I were trying to decide what he said about something. By listening to the recording we realised he actually said something different than we thought.
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)

Posts.Title: scheduling surgery after a holiday.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 Good luck on Wednesday. It will be over before you know it. I remember the nurse giving me a "coctail" shot right before getting wheeled in. I felt GREAT for a few minutes and the next thing I knew I was waking up in the recovery room. Piece of cake. Make sure you have a Netflix subscription so you can binge watch your favorite shows and enjoy not having to get up to go to the bathroom for 7 days! Yep, not only did I subscribe to netflix for the first time, I have never seen the Lord of the Rings trilogy or the hobbit movies, I never could find the time, so all 6 dvds are sitting on a shelf waiting to be played.

Everything so far is just as described by those who have gone before. Thanks for the info I knew what to expect. Will go back next wed for cath removal and hopefully find out the path report on the prostate.
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: scheduling surgery after a holiday.....

Posts.Content: Here I sit with my date with Mr Da Vinci scheduled for wed morning. I scheduled it after Thanksgiving thinking I could enjoy the holiday then go have it done. I would now advise others to alter that planning some because: 1. Thanksgiving is the kickoff of the cold and flu season. Families gather together to share holiday cheer and each others colds. After spending much of the time listening to everyone hacking and coughing I spent most of the weekend wondering if I was going to come down with something in time for surgery. Last year my nieces boyfriend showed up for Thanksgiving dinner running a 101 temp and infected us all. I had forgotten about that. So far I'am doing ok.... 2. Many on these boards have advised guys going for surgery to have as much sex as possible in the days before. Thats hard to do with a house full of family who usually arent there. I've been trying to lure my wife back to a bathroom, much like guys on an airplane trying to entice their girls back to the bathroom to join "the mile high club". The above would also apply to Christmas or Easter, while much of what I typed was firmly toung in cheek, there is some truth to it, and wish I had a week or so in between the holiday and surgery. Today I've been building my nest in the spare bedroom, recliner and tv are prepaired for when I come home. Thanks to everyone for their advice, I'll see you on the other side....
Posts.Signature: Age 54 no previous PSA data. PSA in Feb 6.1, 2nd PSA April 5.6, biopsy 5/17/18 2 of 12 cores Gleason 6, left side 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4), confirmed by Dr Epstiens lab. RALP on 11/28/18 Post surgical pathology Gleason 7 (3+4)
Posts.Title: scheduling surgery after a holiday.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 Good luck on Wednesday. It will be over before you know it. I remember the nurse giving me a "coctail" shot right before getting wheeled in. I felt GREAT for a few minutes and the next thing I knew I was waking up in the recovery room. Piece of cake. Make sure you have a Netflix subscription so you can binge watch your favorite shows and enjoy not having to get up to go to the bathroom for 7 days! Yep, not only did I subscribe to netflix for the first time, I have never seen the Lord of the Rings trilogy or the hobbit movies, I never could find the time, so all 6 dvds are sitting on a shelf waiting to be played.

Posts.Title: scheduling surgery after a holiday.....

Posts.Content: I left the big bag on all week and just stayed in the house, I carried it around in a bucket. I didnt have to empty it as often as a leg bag, and I was worried if I had my feet up with a leg bag the urine back feeding and causing a UTI. I dont know if that could happen, but I worried about it none the less. It was not hard at all for me to empty the big bag myself. I think it was day 4 before I finally went #2. As others said dont strain trying to force it, let it happen in its own time. the week will pass before you know it, and you'll have that thing out of there.

Posts.Title: 2nd day postop

Age.Phrase: looking at Depends online at 54 years old  sigh <Z> <Z>

PatientDecided.Sample: I had a very experienced surgeon, and Because I had an intermediate risk cancer, I was able to put off my surgery for 2 months due to some things going on in my life, and I spent that time practicing Kagels. And even though I'am not ripped like I was when I was 18, I'am in fairly decent shape for my age....I know I'am very fortunate from what I have read, and I wonder what I owe that good fortune to, and if it would help others facing surgery. I had a very experienced surgeon, and Because I had an intermediate risk cancer, I was able to put off my surgery for 2 months due to some things going on in my life, and I spent that time practicing Kagels....
